comments.commentBody: Its the same as when the tobacco companies used to do "good" by sponsoring sporting events etc.  Ben and Jerry and Starbucks get their customers addicted to unhealthy fat, sugar and caffeine (in Starbucks' case) and then they want to wash their hands by doing "good deeds".

The laughable part of progressive economic thought is it's belief that governments are more moral that businesses.  Have you people ever read any history? One of the reasons capitalism (not crony capitalism) is better than government control of economic decisions by law (and, by ultimately police power), is the vast decentralization of decision making when individual businesses make there own decisions.   Will this result in everyone acting in a way we all believe to be moral?  Of course not.  But how naive must you be to believe that taking these decisions from owners and handing them to politicians and bureaucrats will result in greater morality.  A strange fairy tale you progressives tell in matters of economics.

Individual corporations should not be responsible for their employees' health care expenses.

The USA should do what EVERY other nation in the OECD (about 35 nations that are considered "first world" nations) does. Health care should be a right and the government should pay for health care just like it pays for education, police protection, fire protection and other public goods.

This is a PRO-BUSINESS policy because it will take the shackles off of entrepreneurs and employees. Entrepreneurs can now start and expand their businesses when they can't now. Employees do not have to stay in lousy jobs that they hate just because they're working for a big company that can afford health insurance bills.

And from a taxes perspective, it's a great investment for the government just like education is. Health care costs are way, way, way, way lower in ALL the other OECD nations and they live much, much, much longer and better.

We need to be a civilized nation.

I suppose it is fine that Starbucks is trying to do good as it does well, but there are serious limits to that approach.

Individual corporations doing well is not going to come close to achieving the social change that is needed. Individual companies can only pay so well, provide a certain amount of benefits, achieve a certain level of environmental responsibility, etc. before some competitor will see an opening to undercut them on prices by doing less good. As such, doing good may work for a subset of niche industries (like coffee shops) or niche companies (like Ben & Jerry's), but it simply cannot work on a large scale.

The simple fact is that the free market system virtually ensures that corporations will be amoral, as they have to do what they can to make a profit. That is why the way to achieve good is not by counting on corporations, but instead by using government to achieve higher wages, access to health insurance, environmental protection, etc. By having government set and enforce rules on these and other issues, companies less interested in doing good cannot undercut those interested who would like to do good.

So it is nice that Starbucks wants to do some good. But it won't solve our problems, and we have to make sure it does not distract us from the need to ensure that government establishes the rules and policies needed to improve society.

Per the article "i[n] December, a Bain-run fund in which a Romney family blind trust has holdings purchased the video surveillance division of a Chinese company that claims to be the largest supplier to the government’s Safe Cities program, a highly advanced monitoring system that allows the authorities to watch over university campuses, hospitals, mosques and movie theaters from centralized command posts."

The company, Uniview Technologies, produces “infrared antiriot” cameras and software that enable police officials in different locales to share images in real time through the Internet. "

Such surveillance systems are often used to combat crime and the manufacturer has no control over whether they are used for other purposes. But human rights advocates say in China they are also used to intimidate and monitor political and religious dissidents"

In short, this is a very indirect and ineffective way to promote change and freedom in China. These human rights agencies should focus their energy lobbying the U.S. government to flex more diplomatic muscle. China enjoys most-favored-nation trading status with the U.S. Let's start there. Of course, if we are serious about wanting to improve conditions in China, get ready to say goodbye to cheap-as-dirt consumer electronics.

I'm not sure what I think about surrogacy. I can see the ethical issues at stake, and yet . . . as I read through the comments I'm bothered by how indignant privileged NYT readers are that an adult woman might consent to bodily and possibly risky labor (pun intended) in exchange for money.
Um, hello?!
Men, women, and children around the world put their bodies and their health at risk every day in exchange for pitful sums of money so that NYT readers can have the latest cool iPhone, lettuce on their plates, cheap clothes and shoes in their closets, an excess of toys in their kids' bedrooms, and a clichéd bouquet of roses on Valentine's Day.

Should surrogacy be allowed to exist? Perhaps not. But don't pretend it's because you care about the health of the Indian woman. If it's legal and controlled and transparent, and an individual woman in India weighs the risks and benefits and decides to do it, and another woman is deliriously happy with her new family, who are you to cast stones?

I think this is a very touching story, and am less troubled by the possible exploitation of the surrogate in this particular case as it seems Mrs. Arieff truly did build a relationship with Vaina. I'm not sure how common it is, though, for women to move to India during their surrogate's pregnancy or to go back and to maintain a relationship afterwards, let alone visit years later. If this were always the way it was done, that would be ideal...unforunately, I don't think this is the typical relationship.
